This diagram illustrates the process of paper-making./This diagram shows how paper is made.
First/First of all, logs are delivered to a paper mill, where the bark is removed and the wood is cut into small chips.
Next/Second, the wood chips are pulped, either using chemicals or in a pulping machine.
Pulping breaks down the internal structure of the wood and enables/allows the natural oils to be removed.
Once/After the wood has been pulped, the pulp is bleached in order to remove impurities. /…is bleached so that impurities can be removed.
The next stage is to feed the pulp into the paper machine, where it is mixed with water and then poured onto a wire conveyor belt.
As the pulp travels along the conveyor belt, the water drains away. This causes the solid material to sink to the bottom, forming a layer of paper.
At this point the new paper is still wet, so it is passed between large heated rollers, which press out the remaining water and simultaneously dry the paper/…dry the paper at the same time.
The final stage is to wind the paper onto large rolls./Finally, the paper is wound onto large rolls.

idioms.text: be home and free (North American English) (British English be home and dry)
idioms.sense: to have done something successfully, especially when it was difficult
examples: I could see the finish line and thought I was home free.

idioms.sense: informal; relaxed
examples: Life was never going to be so free and easy again.

idioms.sense: if you give somebody a free pass or somebody gets a free pass, they are not punished for something bad they have done, or they are given permission to do something bad
examples: This time he gets a free pass but if he does it again, he’ll be sent to jail.
Just because someone has expensive designer gear, it doesn't mean they have a free pass to be mean to my staff.

idioms.text: get, have, etc. a free hand
idioms.sense: to get, have, etc. the opportunity to do what you want to do and to make your own decisions
examples: I was given a free hand in designing the syllabus.

idioms.text: get, take, etc. a free ride
idioms.sense: to get or take something without paying because somebody else is paying for it

idioms.text: give/allow somebody/something free/full rein | give/allow free/full rein to something
idioms.sense: to give somebody complete freedom of action; to allow a feeling to be expressed freely
examples: The designer was given free rein.
The script allows full rein to her larger-than-life acting style.
When I paint I just give my imagination free rein.

idioms.sense: used as a reply when somebody suggests that you should not do something, or when somebody has asked permission or said they are going to do something
examples: It's a free country; I'll say what I like!
Wear what you like. It's a free country.
‘It's a free country!’ he shouted. ‘I can do what I like!’

idioms.text: there’s no such thing as a free lunch
idioms.sense: used to say that it is not possible to get something for nothing
to be allowed to leave court, etc., without receiving any punishment
examples: She was acquitted and walked free from court.

senses.text: violent physical action used to obtain or achieve something
examples: The release of the hostages could not be achieved without the use of force.

by force The rioters were taken away by force.

plans to seize power by force of arms (= by military force)
The regulations allow the use of force if necessary.

We will achieve much more by persuasion than by brute force.
the force of the explosion/impact
The shopping centre took the full force of the blast.
You have to apply some force to move the lever.
with force She hits the ball with amazing force for someone so small.
He staggered backwards from the force of the blow.
The force of the explosion hurled bodies into the air.
The waves were breaking against the rocks with great force.
A thick wall shielded us from the force of the wind.
They realized the force of her argument.
a leader who inspired others with the force of his personality
by force of something He controlled himself by sheer force of will.
with force Grant drove the point home with considerable force.

I felt the full force of her criticism.
She used her sheer force of personality to keep the family together.

the forces of good/evil

a force for something a force for good/evil

a member of the sales force

coalition/allied forces
a peacekeeping force

a token force of only 300 men

UN forces operating in the region

a UN deadline for the withdrawal of forces

life in the forces

strategic nuclear forces.

the force of gravity
the sun's magnetic force

lateral forces acting on the car's suspension
the attractive and repulsive forces between individual particles
a force 9 gale
a gale force wind

hurricane-force winds

idioms.sense: to cause a law, rule, etc. to start being used
examples: They are hoping to bring the new legislation into force before the end of the year.

idioms.sense: to start being used
examples: When do the new regulations come into force?
The new law comes into force as from midnight tomorrow.

idioms.sense: if you do something from or out of force of habit, you do it without thinking about it and in a particular way because you have always done it that way in the past
examples: It's force of habit that gets me out of bed at 6.15 each morning.

idioms.sense: a person with a very strong personality who is full of energy, very determined and difficult for others to resist
examples: Gerard is a force of nature, continually pursuing his target when everyone else is ready to give up.

idioms.sense: the power of the wind, rain, etc., especially when it causes damage or harm
examples: They were fighting a losing battle against the forces of nature.

idioms.sense: in large numbersbeing used
examples: Protesters turned out in force.
The new regulations are now in force.
Several archaic laws are still in force.
Some laws relating to obsolete customs are still in force.

idioms.sense: to work together in order to achieve a shared aim
examples: The two firms joined forces to win the contract.
The two companies have joined forces to form a new consortium.

idioms.sense: a person or group that no longer has any power or influence
examples: The opposition party is now a spent political force.

idioms.sense: to be pleased because somebody has made you feel important or special
examples: He was flattered by her attention.
I felt flattered at being asked to give a lecture.
She was flattered to hear that he had been asking about her.

idioms.sense: to be or feel unfairly treated
examples: She has every right to feel hard done by—her parents have given her nothing.

idioms.sense: to feel proud and happy
examples: I was honoured to have been mentioned in his speech.
‘Would you be my best man?’ ‘I’d be honoured.’

idioms.text: be/feel like jelly | turn to jelly
idioms.sense: to feel weak because you are nervous
to realize that you are getting old, especially compared with people you are with who are younger than you
used to tell somebody that they are allowed to do something
examples: Feel free to ask questions if you don't understand.
‘Can I use your phone?’ ‘Feel free.’

idioms.sense: to feel happy, confident, etc.
examples: It makes me feel good to know my work is appreciated.

idioms.sense: to be certain about something even though you do not have any direct proof and cannot explain why you are certain
examples: I know I'm going to fail this exam—I can feel it in my bones.

idioms.sense: to want to have or do something
examples: I feel like a drink.
We all felt like celebrating.
He felt like bursting into tears.
We'll go for a walk if you feel like it.

idioms.sense: to not have enough money
examples: Lots of people who have lost their jobs are starting to feel the pinch.

idioms.sense: to move along carefully, for example when it is dark, by touching walls, objects, etc.to be careful about how you do things, usually because you are in a situation that you are not familiar with
examples: She was new in the job, still feeling her way.

idioms.sense: to feel that you must do something because of your sense of moral duty
examples: She felt honour-bound to attend as she had promised to.

idioms.text: look/feel like death warmed up (British English) (North American English like death warmed over)
idioms.sense: to look or feel very ill or tired
to look/feel extremely good

idioms.sense: to look or feel stupid, weak, ashamed, etc.
examples: There’s no need to make me look small in front of all these people.

idioms.sense: to do something to make people very aware of the fact that you are there; to have a strong influence on a group of people or a situation
examples: She’s only been here a couple of weeks but she is already making her presence felt.

idioms.text: not be/feel up to the mark
idioms.sense: not to feel as well or lively as usual
examples: I’m not feeling up to the mark at the moment.

idioms.sense: to not feel healthy and well
examples: I’m not quite feeling myself today.

walking around the house in bare feet (= not wearing shoes or socks)

idioms.text: the boot is on the other foot (British English) (North American English the shoe is on the other foot)
idioms.sense: used to say that a situation has changed so that somebody now has power or authority over the person who used to have power or authority over them

idioms.text: cut the ground from under somebody’s feet
idioms.sense: to suddenly cause somebody’s idea or plan to fail by doing something to stop them from continuing with it
to be deliberately slow in doing something or in making a decision
to be lucky in finding yourself in a good situation, or in getting out of a difficult situation
examples: You landed on your feet, getting such a well-paid job with so little experience.

examples: He landed feet first.

examples: I only recently joined the firm so I'm still finding my feet.

examples: ‘Ian can't come because he's tired.’ ‘Tired my foot! Lazy more like!’

examples: We were covered from head to foot in mud.

examples: He was going to ask her but he got cold feet and said nothing.

examples: At that time he was a young actor, just getting his feet wet.

examples: I always wanted to work in TV but it took me two years to get a foot in the door.

examples: When the actor was imprisoned for drug offences, his fans were upset to find that their hero had feet of clay.

idioms.sense: to be involved in or connected with two different groups, especially ones that oppose each other

idioms.text: have one foot in the grave
idioms.sense: to be so old or ill that you are not likely to live much longer

idioms.text: have the world at your feet
idioms.sense: to be very successful and admired
wearing socks or stockings but not shoes

idioms.sense: to not delay in getting things done
(to put somebody) at a disadvantage or in difficulty

examples: Sue's back on her feet again after her operation.
The new chairman hopes to get the company back on its feet within six months.
She was too weak to stand.
Stand still when I’m talking to you!
Please don’t get up!
Stand up straight!
Everyone would stand up when the teacher entered the classroom.
Would you all rise, please, to welcome our visiting speaker.
I helped her to get to her feet.
I’ve been on my feet all day.

idioms.text: on the front foot (especially British English)
idioms.sense: at an advantagetaking positive steps to achieve something
examples: They allowed the home side to get on the front foot right at the start.
He has been firmly on the front foot, calling for politicians and police to intervene.

idioms.sense: a way of referring to children when somebody wants, or is going to have, a baby
examples: We can't wait to hear the patter of tiny feet.

idioms.text: pull the rug (out) from under somebody’s feet
idioms.sense: to take help or support away from somebody suddenly
to make a great effort to do something, especially if it is difficult or you are feeling tired
to sit down and relax, especially with your feet raised and supported
examples: After a hard day's work, it's nice to get home and put your feet up.

idioms.sense: to be very strict in opposing what somebody wishes to doto drive faster
examples: You've got to put your foot down and make him stop seeing her.
She put her foot down and roared past them.

idioms.text: put your foot in it (British English) (also put your foot in your mouth North American English, British English)
idioms.sense: to say or do something that upsets, offends or embarrasses somebody
examples: I really put my foot in it with Ella—I didn't know she'd split up with Tom.

idioms.sense: to make a mistake
examples: In the last two games he has hardly put a foot wrong.

idioms.sense: to enter or visit a place
examples: the first man to set foot on the moon
I vowed never to set foot in the place again.

idioms.sense: to make somebody/something independent or successful
examples: His business sense helped set the club on its feet again.

idioms.sense: to do or say something that will cause you a lot of trouble or harm, especially when you are trying to get an advantage for yourself
to admire somebody very much, especially a teacher or somebody from whom you try to learn
to be independent and able to take care of yourself
examples: When his parents died he had to learn to stand on his own two feet.

idioms.sense: to make somebody fall suddenly and deeply in love with you
examples: She’s waiting for some hero to come and sweep her off her feet.

idioms.text: take the weight off your feet
idioms.sense: to sit down and rest, especially when you are tired
examples: Come and sit down and take the weight off your feet for a while.

idioms.sense: to be able to think and react to things very quickly and effectively without any preparation
in the way; stopping you from working, etc.
examples: I don't want you kids under my feet while I'm cooking.

idioms.sense: to show what you think about something by going or not going somewhere
examples: Shoppers voted with their feet and avoided the store.

idioms.text: wait on somebody hand and foot
idioms.sense: to take care of somebody’s needs so well that they do not have to do anything for themselves
examples: He seems to expect me to wait on him hand and foot.

idioms.sense: to make somebody walk so far or so fast that they are very tired
examples: I hope I haven’t walked you off your feet.

result.note: In sense 15 flied  /flaɪd/  /flaɪd/is used for the past tense and past participle.

senses.text: to move through the air, using wings
examples: Penguins can't fly.
+ adv./prep. A stork flew slowly past.
A wasp had flown in through the window.
Geese fly south in the fall.
fly (from A) (to B) They were on a plane flying from London to New York.
fly (to B) (from A) Lufthansa fly to La Paz from Frankfurt.
+ adv./prep. Enemy planes fly overhead.
to fly at the speed of sound
The aircraft was declared fully functional and fit to fly.
Is this the first time that you've flown?
fly (from A) (to B) I'm flying to Hong Kong tomorrow.
fly + adv./prep. I was flying home to visit my family.
+ noun I always fly business class.
We're flying KLM.
He's learning to fly.
fly something a pilot trained to fly large passenger planes
children flying kites
She's trained to fly passenger planes, not military jets.
You'll have to fly the helicopter over some dangerous territory.
The stranded tourists were finally flown home.
He had flowers specially flown in for the ceremony.
Orders were given to fly the prisoners to the US.
Some birds fly huge distances when they migrate.
Who was the first person to fly the Atlantic?
Only four airlines are currently allowed to fly transatlantic routes from Heathrow.
The train was flying along.
She gasped and her hand flew to her mouth.
It's late—I must fly.
(+ adv./prep.) A large stone came flying in through the window.
Several people were hit by flying glass.
+ adj. David gave the door a kick and it flew open.
Doesn't time fly?
fly by/past Summer has just flown by.
Flags were flying at half mast on all public buildings.
fly something to fly the Stars and Stripes
hair flying in the wind
Both suspects have flown the country.
It remains to be seen whether his project will fly.
Her children have flown the nest.

idioms.sense: in a straight line
examples: The villages are no more than a mile apart as the crow flies.

idioms.sense: the wanted person has escaped

idioms.text: (fly) by the seat of your pants
idioms.sense: to act without careful thought and without a plan that you have made in advance, hoping that you will be lucky and be successful
to escape from a place
to show your support for your country, an organization or an idea to encourage or persuade others to do the same
to be successful
examples: British cinema has been flying high recently, winning several coveted awards.

idioms.text: fly in the face of something
idioms.sense: to oppose or be the opposite of something that is usual or expected
examples: Such a proposal is flying in the face of common sense.

idioms.text: fly into a rage, temper, etc.
idioms.sense: to become suddenly very angry
to test out public opinion on a subject
examples: The company is flying a kite to see if this plan provokes any interest.

idioms.sense: to become able to fly and leave its nestto leave home and live somewhere else
examples: Her children have flown the nest.

idioms.text: fly/go off at a tangent (British English) (North American English go off on a tangent)
idioms.sense: to suddenly start saying or doing something that does not seem to be connected to what has gone before
examples: He never sticks to the point but keeps going off at a tangent.
Laura’s mind went off at a tangent.

idioms.sense: to suddenly become very angry
examples: He seems to fly off the handle about the slightest thing these days.

idioms.sense: to stop existing; to disappear completely
examples: As soon as the kids arrived, order went out of the window.

idioms.sense: to fall, especially as a result of not seeing something under your feet
examples: Someone's going to go flying if you don't pick up these toys.

idioms.sense: used to tell somebody to go away and stop annoying you or interfering
to represent your country or organization
examples: Our exporters keep the flag flying at international trade exhibitions.

idioms.sense: to attack somebody by hitting them or speaking angrily to them
examples: He let fly at me with his fist.
She let fly with a stream of abuse.

idioms.text: pigs might fly (British English) (North American English when pigs fly)
idioms.sense: used to show that you do not believe something will ever happen
examples: ‘With a bit of luck, we'll be finished by the end of the year.’ ‘Yes, and pigs might fly!’

idioms.sense: time seems to pass very quickly
examples: How time flies! I've got to go now.
Time has flown since the holiday began.

result.note: For the special uses of for in phrasal verbs, look at the entries for the verbs. For example fall for somebody is in the phrasal verb section at fall.

senses.text: used to show who is intended to have or use something or where something is intended to be put
examples: There's a letter for you.
It's a book for children.
We got a new table for the dining room.
This is the place for me (= I like it very much).
What can I do for you (= how can I help you)?
Can you translate this letter for me?
I took her classes for her while she was sick.
soldiers fighting for their country
a machine for slicing bread
Let's go for a walk.
Are you learning English for pleasure or for your work?
What did you do that for (= Why did you do that)?
The town is famous for its cathedral.
She gave me a watch for my birthday.
He got an award for bravery.
I couldn't speak for laughing.
He didn’t answer for fear of hurting her.
He came to me for advice.
For more information, call this number.
There were over fifty applicants for the job.
I'm going away for a few days.
That's all the news there is for now.
The road went on for miles and miles.
Is this the bus for Chicago?
She knew she was destined for a great future.
an appointment for May 12
We're invited for 7.30.
I'm warning you for the last time—stop talking!
Copies are available for two dollars each.
I'll swap these two bottles for that one.
She's working for an insurance company.
They are anxious for her safety.
Fortunately for us, the weather changed.
I am speaking for everyone in this department.
Shaking your head for ‘No’ is not universal.
Are you for or against the proposal?
They voted for independence in a referendum.
There's a strong case for postponing the exam.
I'm all for (= strongly support) people having fun.
‘What does Naomi think about the move?’ ‘She’s all for it.’
The weather was warm for the time of year.
She's tall for her age.
He’s not bad for a beginner.
That's too much responsibility for a child.
It's useless for us to continue.
There's no need for you to go.
For her to have survived such an ordeal was remarkable.
The box is too heavy for me to lift.
Is it clear enough for you to read?
It's not for me to say why he left.
How to spend the money is for you to decide.
You'll feel better for a good night's sleep.
This room would look more cheerful for a spot of paint.
For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.
For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.

idioms.text: be in for it (British English also be for it)
idioms.sense: to be going to get into trouble or be punished
examples: We'd better hurry or we'll be in for it.

idioms.sense: despiteused to say that something is not important or of no interest or value to you/somebody
examples: For all its clarity of style, the book is not easy reading.
For all I know she's still living in Boston.
You can do what you like, for all I care.
For all the good it's done we might as well not have bothered.

idioms.sense: used to say that something is a typical example of its kind
examples: She might at least have called to explain. There's gratitude for you.
